conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their size and shape depend on the position of the light source relative to the object and the surface where the shadow is cast.
The image shows four objects above slabs, casting shadows labeled A, B, C, and D on the ground. The shadows are positioned to the front right of the objects.
The light source is likely positioned to the back left, as the shadows are cast to the front right of the objects.
If the light source moves further to the back left, the shadows will become longer and shift further to the front right.
The angle of the light will cause the shadows to stretch out more, making them larger and extending further from the objects.
If the light source moves to the back right, the shadows will shift to the front left.
The shadows will become longer but will extend in the opposite direction compared to when the light is on the back left.
Moving the light to the back left will cause shadows A, B, C, and D to shift further to the front right.
Moving the light to the back right will cause shadows A, B, C, and D to shift to the front left.
In both cases, the shadows will become larger because the light is at a more oblique angle to the objects, causing the shadows to stretch out more.
When the light source moves to the back left, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift further to the front right and become larger.
When the light source moves to the back right, shadows A, B, C, and D will shift to the front left and become larger.
